scenario: View homepage with API categories
given: I am a developer visiting the ONE API Portal
when: I land on the homepage
then: I see a clear hero section with value proposition, 4 API category cards (Tracking, Schedules, Booking, Routes), and a 'View Documentation' CTA button
notes: Happy path for homepage first impression

scenario: Navigate from homepage to API Reference
given: I am on the ONE API Portal homepage
when: I click the 'View Documentation' CTA button
then: I am navigated to the API Reference page showing documentation

scenario: View homepage on mobile device
given: I am a developer on a mobile phone
when: I visit the ONE API Portal homepage
then: The hero section and API categories are displayed in a stacked mobile-friendly layout without horizontal scrolling

scenario: Explore API categories on homepage
given: I am on the homepage viewing API categories
when: I see 4 category cards
then: Each card shows category name, icon, brief description (1-2 sentences), and 'Learn more' link

scenario: Navigate to specific API category documentation
given: I am on the homepage
when: I click the 'Learn more' link on the Tracking category card
then: I am navigated to the API Reference page with Tracking category documentation visible

scenario: View category cards with hover state (desktop)
given: I am on the homepage using a desktop browser
when: I hover my mouse over an API category card
then: The card displays a subtle hover effect (elevation or border change)

scenario: Access Getting Started guide from homepage
given: I am on the homepage
when: I click the Getting Started link in the navigation or a CTA
then: I am taken to the Getting Started guide page showing sections: Overview, Obtain Credentials, Authentication, First API Call, Troubleshooting

scenario: Request API credentials via support email
given: I am reading the Getting Started guide Obtain Credentials section
when: I click the 'Contact Support' link
then: My email client opens with a pre-filled template (To: api-support@one-line.com, Subject: API Credential Request, with placeholders for Company Name and Use Case)

scenario: Copy first API call example
given: I am reading the First API Call section of Getting Started guide
when: I view the curl example for GET /shipments
then: I see a highlighted code example with Authorization header and can copy it using a copy button

scenario: Search for endpoint by keyword
given: I am on any page of the portal
when: I type 'track shipment' (â‰¥3 characters) in the search bar
then: An autocomplete dropdown appears showing relevant endpoints like 'GET /shipments/{id}' with brief descriptions

scenario: Navigate to endpoint from search results
given: I have searched for 'tracking' and see results
when: I click on the 'GET /shipments/{id}' search result
then: I am navigated to that endpoint's documentation page

scenario: Search with no results found
given: I am using the search bar
when: I type 'xyz123invalid' (a keyword that doesn't exist)
then: I see a message 'No results found. Try different keywords' in the dropdown

scenario: Close search results with Escape key
given: I have opened the search dropdown
when: I press the Escape key
then: The search dropdown closes

scenario: Browse API Reference by category
given: I am on the API Reference page
when: I view the sidebar navigation
then: I see collapsible categories (Tracking, Schedules, Booking, Routes) with endpoint lists and endpoint count per category

scenario: Expand category and navigate to endpoint
given: I am viewing the API Reference sidebar with categories collapsed
when: I click the Tracking category
then: The category expands showing a list of endpoints alphabetically, and I can click an endpoint to scroll to its documentation

scenario: View API Reference on mobile
given: I am on the API Reference page using a mobile device
when: I access the sidebar navigation
then: The sidebar is hidden by default and accessible via a hamburger menu icon which I can tap to view categories and endpoints

scenario: View comprehensive endpoint documentation
given: I am viewing an endpoint in the API Reference
when: I scroll through the endpoint documentation
then: I see: endpoint URL, HTTP method badge, description, authentication requirements, request parameters table (with Name/Type/Required/Description columns), response schema with example JSON, and error codes table

scenario: Copy code example from endpoint docs
given: I am viewing endpoint documentation with code examples
when: I click the 'Copy' button on a code block
then: The code is copied to my clipboard and the button shows 'Copied!' feedback for 2 seconds

scenario: Toggle between success and error response examples
given: I am viewing an endpoint's response schema section
when: I toggle between success response and error response samples
then: Both response types are shown with properly formatted, syntax-highlighted JSON using realistic sample data

scenario: Switch between code example languages
given: I am viewing endpoint documentation with code examples
when: I click the 'JavaScript' tab from the language tabs (curl, JavaScript, Python, Java)
then: The code example switches to JavaScript showing a complete working example with authentication header, request, and expected response

scenario: Copy code example in different language
given: I have selected the Python language tab
when: I click the 'Copy' button
then: The Python code is copied to my clipboard, the button shows 'Copied!' feedback, and my language selection (Python) is saved for subsequent pages
notes: Copy and persistence of language selection

scenario: View code examples with proper syntax
given: I am viewing code examples in all 4 languages
when: I review the code quality
then: JavaScript uses ES6+ async/await, Python uses requests library, Java uses modern Java 11+ syntax, and all include proper error handling

scenario: View sticky sidebar navigation on scroll
given: I am on the API Reference page (desktop)
when: I scroll down through multiple endpoints
then: The sidebar remains fixed/sticky and highlights the currently visible endpoint as I scroll

scenario: Navigate via sidebar click
given: I am viewing the API Reference with sidebar
when: I click an endpoint in the sidebar
then: The page scrolls smoothly to that endpoint's documentation and highlights it in the sidebar

scenario: Expand/collapse sidebar categories
given: I am viewing the sidebar with a collapsed category
when: I click the category expand icon
then: The category expands with smooth animation showing its endpoints

scenario: View breadcrumb navigation
given: I am viewing a specific endpoint documentation page
when: I look at the top of the content area
then: I see breadcrumbs showing: Home > API Reference > Tracking > GET /shipments, with each level clickable except the current page

scenario: Navigate using breadcrumbs
given: I am on an endpoint documentation page
when: I click 'API Reference' in the breadcrumbs
then: I am navigated to the API Reference overview page

scenario: Use table of contents anchor links
given: I am viewing endpoint documentation
when: I click an anchor link in the table of contents (e.g., #authentication)
then: The page scrolls smoothly to that section, and the URL updates with the hash fragment for sharable deep linking
notes: Anchor link navigation and URL updates

scenario: Search for error code in documentation
given: I encounter a 401 error and need help
when: I search for '401' in the portal search or browse to Error Documentation
then: I find the error documentation showing: 401 Unauthorized, description, common causes (missing/invalid API key), and solution

scenario: Browse error documentation by HTTP status
given: I am on the Error Documentation page
when: I view the list of errors
then: I see errors organized by HTTP status code (400, 401, 403, 404, 429, 500) with ONE LINE-specific error names and descriptions

scenario: Search error docs using search functionality
given: I am using the portal search
when: I type a specific error code '429'
then: The search returns the error documentation for 'Rate Limit Exceeded' in the results

scenario: View detailed error explanation with examples
given: I am viewing error documentation for 400 Bad Request
when: I read the error entry
then: I see: common causes list (2-3 bullet points), example incorrect request (code block), example correct request (code block), and link to related endpoint documentation

scenario: Navigate to related docs from error explanation
given: I am viewing a 401 Unauthorized error explanation
when: I click the 'related documentation' link
then: I am navigated to the Authentication section of Getting Started or relevant endpoint docs

scenario: Understand error with plain language
given: I am a junior developer viewing error documentation
when: I read the error explanations
then: The explanations use plain language, realistic examples in curl format, and actionable troubleshooting steps

scenario: View authentication documentation
given: I am reading the Authentication section
when: I view the documentation
then: I see: API key format (Bearer token), how to include it in Authorization header, and a clear curl example with 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY'

scenario: Understand rate limits
given: I am reading the Rate Limits section
when: I review the documentation
then: I see: requests per minute/hour limits (e.g., 100/min, 1000/hour), how to check remaining quota via response headers (X-RateLimit-Remaining), and 429 error behavior with Retry-After header

scenario: Review authentication security best practices
given: I am reading the authentication docs
when: I scroll to security best practices
then: I see recommendations: don't commit API keys to version control, rotate keys periodically, use environment variables

scenario: View changelog page with recent updates
given: Portal has API changes documented
when: I navigate to the Changelog page from main navigation
then: I see a list of changelog entries sorted by date (newest first), with each entry showing date (YYYY-MM-DD), update type tag (Added/Changed/Fixed/Deprecated/Removed), and short summary

scenario: Identify breaking changes in changelog
given: Changelog includes a breaking change
when: I browse the changelog
then: I see a changelog entry prominently marked with a 'Breaking Change' badge or tag

scenario: Subscribe to changelog updates via RSS
given: Changelog has RSS feed available (optional feature)
when: I view the Changelog page
then: I see an option to subscribe to the changelog via RSS feed

scenario: Expand changelog entry for details
given: I am viewing the changelog with collapsed entries
when: I click a changelog entry to expand it
then: The entry expands smoothly showing detailed description, affected endpoints list (with URLs and HTTP methods), migration guide with before/after code examples, and links to updated documentation

scenario: View migration guide for breaking change
given: A breaking change is documented in changelog
when: I expand that changelog entry
then: The migration guide clearly explains what changed with before/after code examples and how to update existing integrations

scenario: Navigate to updated docs from changelog
given: I have expanded a changelog entry
when: I click the 'View updated docs' link for an affected endpoint
then: I am navigated to that endpoint's documentation page, ideally with anchor to the changed section

scenario: View recently updated indicator on endpoint docs
given: An endpoint was updated recently (within 30 days)
when: I visit that endpoint's documentation
then: I see a 'Recently updated' badge or indicator on changed fields showing update date

scenario: Navigate back to changelog from endpoint
given: I navigated from changelog to endpoint docs
when: I want to return to the changelog
then: I can use breadcrumbs or back button showing 'Changelog' as previous page to navigate back

scenario: Rate documentation page helpfulness
given: I have read an endpoint documentation page
when: I scroll to the bottom and see the feedback widget
then: I click a star rating (e.g., 4 stars) and click Submit, then see 'Thank you for your feedback!' confirmation

scenario: Submit feedback without authentication
given: I am an anonymous user (not logged in)
when: I rate a documentation page
then: My feedback is recorded successfully without requiring login or authentication

scenario: View feedback widget on mobile
given: I am viewing documentation on mobile
when: I scroll to the feedback widget
then: The widget is responsive, doesn't block content, and is easy to interact with on a small screen

scenario: Submit rating with optional written comment
given: I am viewing the feedback widget
when: I click 4 stars, type a comment 'The examples are helpful' (within 500 char limit), and click Submit
then: Both my rating and comment are submitted, and I see confirmation message

scenario: Respect character limit in feedback comment
given: I am typing a comment in the feedback widget
when: I type 500 characters
then: The character count shows '500/500', and when I try to type more, input stops accepting characters and shows 'Limit reached' warning

scenario: Expand text input for longer feedback
given: I am using the feedback widget
when: I click in the text input field
then: The field expands to a multi-line textarea (3-5 rows) allowing me to write longer feedback comfortably
